Name: Ethylbenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (1995): Ethyl benzene, if swallowed, may cause chemical pneumonia due to misswallowing. The substance is a hydrocarbon, the kinematic viscosity of which stands at 0.74mm3/s (25degC).

Name: Styrene
Rationale for classification: Based on the fact that styrene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.772 mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value).

Name: heptan-3-one
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: p-Xylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed." Based on the fact that p-xylene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.704mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value).

Name: 1,2-Dichloroethane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human symptoms: "May cause pulmonary edema if inhaled and chemical pneumonia if swallowed." (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)), "Pulmonary congestion/edema, dyspnea and bronchitis were observed in deceased patients (due to acute ingestion), while pulmonary edema can be attributed to chemical pneumonia due to misswallowing" (ATSDR (2001)).

Name: Allyl alcohol
Rationale for classification: Based on its kinematic viscosity and being a primary alcohol containing 3-13 carbon atoms.

Name: 2-Pentanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: Methyl isobutyl ketone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13) and containing an isobutyl alcohol and ketone composed of carbon atoms (n>=13).

Name: 1-methylethyl acetate
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2 based on the statement that there is a risk of chemical pneumonia in case of swalloed by aspiration into the lungs (ICSC (1998)), and the statement that of risk of chemical pneumonia by intake (SITTIG (47th, 2002)). Since it was unknown whether it is the description based on human case, We did not classify it as Category 1.

Name: m-Xylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed." Based on the fact that m-xylene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.676mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value).

Name: m-Divinylbenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the fact that the substance is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 1.17mm2/s (20degC).

Name: 1,3,5-Trimethylbenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the fact that the substance is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 1.336mm2/s (20degC).

Name: Diisobutyl ketone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: The dynamic viscosity at 21 degree C is 1.1mm2/s (calculated from The Solvent Pocket Book data), and diisobutyl ketone is a ketone with a carbon number of 13 or less, therefore we classified it as Category 2.

Name: Methyl cyclohexane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and the dynmic viscosity is about 0.95 mm2/s at 20 degrees C ( viscosity/density = 0.732 (mPas)/0.7694 (g/cm3)), and the dynamic viscosity at 40 degrees C is considered to be less than 20.5 mm2/s, we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Toluene
Rationale for classification: Based on the fact that toluene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.65 mm2/s (25degC) (calculated value).

Name: Chlorobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2003): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed".

Name: Cyclohexanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: In this surver, no data of the aspiration breathing apparatus hazards, however, the dynamic viscosity is considered to be (40 degrees C) <14mm2/s (dynamic viscosity = 2.13mm 2/s (24 degrees C) (based on Renzo (3rd, 1986))), moreover, "there were also the authorities which classified the ketone of 13 or less carbon atoms," therefore we classified it as Category 2.

Name: Pentane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and the dynamic viscosity is 0.374mm2/s at 20 degrees C (calculated from the viscosity 0.234mPs-s, and the density of 0.62624g/cm3 at 20 degrees C), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: 2-Hexanone, 5-methyl-
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: 2-Heptanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: Hexane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and the dynamic viscosity at 40 degrees C is 20.5mm2/s or less, we classified it as Category 1. There was description of chemical pneumonia by the Aspiration in the rat (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)).

Name: Cyclohexane
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia by misswallowing of the liquid."(ICSC(J), 1999)

Name: Cyclohexene
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia by misswallowing of the liquid."(ICSC(J), 1999)

Name: Octane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement of hydrocarbon of dynamic viscosity of 0.735mm 2/s (calculated value), the risk of chemical pneumonia (ICSC (1997)), and fear of chemical pneumonia by aspiration (HSDB (2005)), it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Nonane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and its dynamic viscosity is 20.5mm2/s or less at 40 degrees C (the dynamic viscosity converted from viscosity 0.55cP at 40 degrees C using density 0.7176-0.7192 g/cm3 is 0.8mm2/s), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: 1-Octanol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed (liquid)."

Name: Decan-1-ol
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: "After aspiration of 0.2 mL of the substance, nine out of the nine rats died" (Patty (5th, 2001)) and "it is harmful if inhaled, and it shows solubility behavior like the hydrocarbons in a small quantity (0.2 mL)" (HSDB (2006)). Moreover, the kinematic viscosity at 20degC is calculated to be 16.6 mm2/s (20degC), and at 40degC, the viscosity is expected to be 20.5 mm2/s or less. Therefore, it is classified into Category 1.

Name: heptan-4-one
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less (though no data available on chemical pneumonia)

Name: 2-Octanol
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of  "possible to be classified into Aspiration hazard." (ICSC(J), 2002)

Name: Tetrachloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) 2003: "Effects of short-term exposure - may cause chemical pneumonia if swallowed."

Name: Beryllium oxide
Rationale for classification:
"Inhalation of dust or fume may cause chemical pneumonia" (ICSC (J) (2000)).
According to the technical guideline, "metal dust of beryllium fluoride may produce chemical pneumonia following inhalation exposure etc. In the ICSC card, under the heading of 'important data,' it says 'inhalation of dust/fume may cause chemical pneumonia.

Name: Calcium oxide
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "aspiration pneumonia to human beings."(HSDB, 2005)

Name: Potassium hydroxide
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the statement of die of pneumonia by aspiration (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Xylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC(J)(2002) regarding o-xylene, m-xylene and p-xylene: "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed".

Name: methylcyclohexanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13) and containing an isobutyl alcohol and ketone composed of carbon atoms (n>=13).

Name: Butyl acrylate
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to classify into Aspiration hazard." (ICSC Card)

Name: Heptane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and the dynamic viscosity is 0.61mm2/s at 20 degrees C (calculated from the viscosity 0.4169 mPa-s and the density 0.68376g/cm3 at 20 degrees C), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: 2-Norbornene, 5-ethylidene-
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the description of severe pneumonia by aspiration in human (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and the description that when the fluid is swallowed, there is a risk of chemical pneumonitis by aspiration (ICSC (J), (1999)).

Name: Methyl t-butyl ether
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since there is a description that when the liquid is swallowed, the chemical pneumonia may be occurred in aspiration into lungs (MOE Risk Assessment the 4th volume (2005)), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Blasticidin S
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "aspiration pneumonitis as an acute symptom in human beings." (HSDB, 2004)

Name: 2-(Dimethylamino)ethyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "alveolar hemorrhage (due probably to irritation caused by the reflux of the orally administered substance), pulmonary edema/congestion, fatal cases" (SIDS (2003)). The kinematic viscosity stands at 1.31mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value (2005)).

Name: chlorophenol
Classification: o-: Classification not possible; m-: Classification not possible; p-: Classification not possible
Rationale for classification: No data available (o-, m-, p-)

Name: Benzene, trimethyl-
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Trimethyl benzene is a hydrocarbon. There is a descriptionthat among the three isomers, the viscosity of 1, 2, 4-trimethyl benzene and 1, 3, 5-trimethyl benzene are 0.730mPas (30 degrees C) and 1.154mPas (20 degrees C), respectively (Lange (14th, 1992)). Based on these each viscosity data and on the fact that the densities of these 3 isomers are smaller than 0.9, it is judged that the dynamic viscosity of trimethyl benzene at 40 degrees C (the mixture of three isomers) is fully less than 20.5mm 2/s. Moreover, there is a description that [there is a risk of chemical pneumonia by aspiration if the fluid is swallowed](ICSC (J) (2002)), and 1, 2, 3-trimethyl benzene and 1, 3, 5-trimethyl benzene are explained. Furthermore, there is the description that [bronchitis or chemical pneumonia will be caused if the liquid enters into the lungs](SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and we classified it as Category 1 based on these descriptions.

Name: Cyclopentane
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: There is the descriptions that aspiration causes chemical pneumonia (the documents of Priority 1 (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and 2 (ICSC(J) (1994); SITTIG (4th, 2002))), therefore we classified it as Category 1.

Name: 3-Chloro-2-methylprop-1-ene
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since there is a risk of chemical pneumonia by aspiration (ICSC (1998)) and the kinematic viscosity is calculated to be 0.458 (20degC) and the figure is expected to be lower at 40degC, it was classified into Category 1.

Name: 2-Butanone, 3-methyl-
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: hexan-2-one
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13) and containing an isobutyl alcohol and ketone composed of carbon atoms (n>=13).

Name: 1-Hexene
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of a hydrocarbon and the dynamic viscosity: 0.39mm2/s at 25degC.

Name: Ethane, 1,1'-oxybis
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to be classified into Aspiration hazard (ICSC)"

Name: Aniline
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Distillates (petroleum), straight-run middle
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia by misswallowing of the liquid." (ATSDR, 1995)

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: 2-Propanol
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Although we have no information for human, the death of cardiopulmonary arrest is observed within 24 hours by the intratracheal administration in the rat (EHC (1990) and PATTY (1994)). And the dynamic viscosity was around 1.6 approximately, we judged that there was aspiration breathing apparatus hazards, and we classified it as Category 2.

Name: Acetone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: The calculated dynamic viscosity is 0.426mm2/sec and there was not the animal data of chemical pneumonia, however, it was the ketone of under C13, therefore it was classified into  Category 2.

Name: 1-Propanol
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13).

Name: 1-Butanol
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13) and containing an isobutyl alcohol and ketone composed of carbon atoms (n>=13).

Name: Benzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2003): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed." Based on the fact that benzene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.740mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Carbon disulfide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in CICAD 46 (2002) and ICSC (J) (2000): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed."

Name: 2-Propanamine
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia by misswallowing of the liquid."(ICSC(J), 1999)

Name: 1,1-Dichloroethylene; Vinylydene dichloride
Rationale for classification: May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed (ICSC (J) (2000)), "In case of accidental ingestion, rinsing the mouth with water is recommended. An attempt to induce vomiting is not advised as the material may enter the pharynx and/or lung" (EHC 100 (1990)).

Name: Nitric acid
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the statement that of chemical lobar pneumonia by aspiration (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Dicyclopentadiene
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Although it is a polycyclic hydrocarbon corresponded by dynamic viscosity, the industrial products contain monocyclic substance (cyclopentadiene) a lot. We classified it as "Category 1."

Name: Iron trichloride
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "aspiration pneumonia" (HSDB, 2005)

Name: Beryllium fluoride
Rationale for classification:
"Inhalation of dust or fume may cause chemical pneumonia" (ICSC (J) (2000)).
According to the technical guideline, "metal dust of beryllium fluoride may produce chemical pneumonia following inhalation exposure etc. In the ICSC card, under the heading of 'important data,' it says 'inhalation of dust/fume may cause chemical pneumonia,' and the following chemicals are listed as examples" (ICSC (J) (2000)). The present substance is assumed to be included in the list and thus classified into Category 2 for "Aspiration hazard."

Name: bromine pentafluoride
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia"(HSDB, 2005)

Name: Butane, 2-methyl-
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon and the dynamic viscosity at 20 degrees C is 0.3615 or 0.3760 mm2/s (calculated from the viscosity 0.224 or 0.233 mPas, and the density 0.61967 g/cm3 at 20 degrees C), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: 1-Propanol, 2-methyl-
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of an isobutyl alcohol (UN Report)

Name: 2-Butanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of being a primary normal alcohol composed of carbon atoms (3<=n>=13) and containing an isobutyl alcohol and ketone composed of carbon atoms (n>=13).

Name: butenone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of a ketone composed of 13 carbon atoms or less.

Name: Trichloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed (liquid)."

Name: Acrylamide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Gasoline, natural
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "human beings cause aspiration pneumonia by an oral ingestion of gasoline." (HSDB, 2004)

Name: Turpentine oil
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that when it is aspirated into the airway by the aspiration (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), DFGOT (Vol.17, 2002), ICSC (J) (2002)), it may cause the chemical pneumonia, we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Kerosine petroleum
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "possible to cause chemical pneumonia by misswallowing of the liquid."(ACGIH, 7th, 2001; EHC 20, 1982)

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 1 based on the reports that ingestion of mineral oil causes the aspiration into the lungs, and as a result it occures the pneumonie huileuses or chemical pneumonia in the human (EHC 20 (1982), IARC 33 (1984), ICSC (2001), ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Demeton-methyl
Classification: O-: Classification not possible; S-: Classification not possible
Rationale for classification: No data available (o-, S-)

Name: Stoddard solvent
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since it is a hydrocarbon, and the 25-degree C dynamic viscosity calculated from the viscosity of the white spirit is 0.87-1.94 mm2/s, and may be 20.5mm2/s or less at 40 degrees C, and there is the descriptions that the aspiration may occuree chemical pneumonia (PATTY (4th, 1994), EHC 187 (1996), and ATSDR (1995)), we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Demeton (mixed isomers)
Classification: Mixture: Classification not possible; O-: Classification not possible; S-: Classification not possible
Rationale for classification: Mixture: no data available; o- and s-: no data available

Name: Sodium alpha-dodecan-1-yl-omega-(sulfonatooxy)poly(oxyethylene)
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Judging from the description about the effects to human that "upper airway edema and dyspnea respiratory distress may be caused by inhalation"(HSDB (2002)), it was classified into Category 1.

Name: o-Xylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed." Based on the fact that o-xylene is a hydrocarbon and has a dynamic viscosity of 0.86mm2/s (25degC) (CERI calculated value).

Name: 1,2,4-Trimethylbenzene
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: ICSC (2002) shows that "oral administration of this liquid may cause chemical pneumonitis if inhaled into the lungs." Furthermore, the kinematic viscosity estimated from the viscosity of 1.00 cP (Chemical Engineers' Handbook) at 25degC and the density 0.872 g/cm3 at 20degC was about 1.15 mm2/s. Since the level at 40degC is expected to be <1.14 mm2/s which is lower than the guidance value of 20.5 mm2/s, it was classified into Category 1.

Name: 3-Pentanone
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: We have a statement that the aspiration into the lungs may occure the chemical pneumonia (HSDB (2005)), and we classified it as Category 2 as it being ketone with the carbon numbers 5.

Name: Benzene, (trichloromethyl)-
Hazard statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since description of "there is a risk of causing chemical pneumonitis by aspiration in swallowing fluid "( ICSC (J) (1995))  was judged to be described based on the evidence of humans etc., we classified into Category 2.

Name: Cumene
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: It is a hydrocarbon and dynamic viscosity is not over 20.5mm [2/s ]. And, there was a description "when the fluid is swallowed, there is a risk of chemical pneumonia by aspiration" (ICSC(ICSC(J), (2000))). Moreover, it is classified as R65 in EU. Therefore, we classified it into Category 1.

Name: alpha-Methylstyrene
Rationale for classification: Based on the fact that the substance is a hydrocarbon according to the GHS definition and has a dynamic viscosity of 1.032mm2/s (20degC).

Name: Blasticiden-S-benzylaminobenzenesulfonate
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since no data of this product, however, blasticidin S (ID 1344, CAS 2079-00-7) is classified as Category 1 because of the aspiration pneumonia as the acute symptoms in human (HSDB, 2004), we judged that this product also had the same characteristics, and we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Coal tar naphtha
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 1 based on that solvent naphtha has dynamic viscosity of 0.949mm 2/s (30 degrees C) (The Solvent Pocket Book (2001)), and that Aromatic solvent A4 (boiling points 196 to 264 degrees C) showed the fatality rates of 5/10 (EHC20 (1982)). In addition, Solvent naphtha (petroleum), light arom. (Cas 64742-95-6), Solvent naphtha (petroleum) and heavy arom. (Cas 64742-94-5) are classified as R65 (may cause lung damage if swallowed.) (ESIS (2006)).

Name: petroleum ether
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 1 based on the fact that the petroleum ether contains pentane and iso hexane as the principal components (NIOSH (1997)), and the pentane is a hydrocarbon and its dynamic viscosity is 0.374mm 2/s at 20 degrees C (calculated from the viscosity 0.234 mPs-s at 20 degrees C, and the density of 0.62624g/cm3).

Name: Petroleum naphtha
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 1 based on the statement that in all species used in the experiment, if a small quantity of petroleum solvent (petroleum naphtha) enters into the airway it causes chemical pneumonia (EHC (1982)), and based on the classification of Xn;R65 (Harmful:may cause lung damage if swallowed) for the EU categorization.

Name: Petroleum benzine
Hazard statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
Rationale for classification: Since the petroleum benzin consists of hexane and heptane, and hexane is hydrocarbon and its dynamic viscosity at 40 degrees C is 20.5mm 2/s or less, we classified it as Category 1. There is a description of chemical pneumona by aspiration of hexane on the rat (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)).
